39103003.review:
If you enjoy programming and have enjoyed any other zachatronics game, I can whole-heartedly recommend TIS-100. 

If you haven't played any zachatronics game before, this is probably not the right game to start with (unless you are a programmer). Infinifactory or Opus Magnum would likely be better first starts into Zach-likes if you don't already like programming. 

TIS-100 is a puzzle game built around a simple assembly programming language. Most of the challenge of the puzzles comes from fitting your program into the processors; yopu need to employ as many tricks as you can to make them small.  After first solving the puzzle, you can see how well other people did (some people are wizards) and improve your solution.

Finishing the first half of the game is hard, but not impossible. Finishing the second half is brutal (I haven't completed it yet, but I also have played less than my hours would imply).

So if you like (puzzles and programming) or you like other zachatronics games I would recomend TIS-100.

39043359.review:
燒腦遊戲
考驗組合語言與平行化的能力
這遊戲的ISA有以下特色
1. instruction較一般MISC少，只有13~14個
2. 一台機器只有1個active register(ACC)可用 (一個BAK register只得透過SWP與SAV來存取)
3. 每台機器的code length限制為15行
相對困難些
並且需考量多台機器間的互動
這樣的架構具有MPMD(multiple program multiple data)平行化的功能

算是蠻好玩的
但前提是玩家必須至少要有基本的組合語言與讀reference manual的能力

還是大推

38779645.review:
[h1]TIS-100 is a game for everyone who enjoys programming in assembly - including those who don't know it yet.[/h1]

The goal of every puzzle is to get your [b]T[/b]esselated [b]I[/b]ntelligence [b]S[/b]ystem to do something - be it multiplying two numbers or filling the screen with an alternating black-white pattern. To accomplish this, you have to program the TIS-100 using its own, very basic programming language. 

[b]If you have a background in programming, don't worry.[/b]
The TIS-100 is different enough to a normal computer that even standard problems like "find the maximum of a sequence" will get you thinking about how to solve them. And even if not, you can always try to optimize your solution for runtime or other statistics, competing with everyone else who plays this game.

[b]If you have no background in programming whatsoever, worry a little bit.[/b]
In theory, the game (or rather the manual) gives you everything you need to know to solve it. It will be hard, and you will need a lot of patience and resistance to frustration - it certainly isn't the easiest introduction to programming (perhaps check out Human Resource Machine). But, if you do manage to beat some of the puzzles, you will get that incredible feeling of having accomplished something by yourself, without someone holding your hand. If you consider yourself good at learning-by-doing, I encourage you to give it a try.

[b]The game does have a story...[/b]
... but it's quite minimalistic. In each puzzle you get a bit of monologue from your uncle, the previous owner of the TIS-100.
I haven't reached the end yet, but what little story there is seems well written and at least makes you curious what the big reveal at the end might be. It serves its purpose, but is certainly not the selling point of this game.

[b]Should you buy it?[/b]
Since you can refund games on Steam now - unless you're quite certain you're not made for pushing numbers around in a coputer, why not? Especially now that it's on sale.

Bonus: If you play this game on a laptop in a public place, e.g. on a train, you'll look like the 1337est H4x0r in the known universe. Promise.

37793210.review:
TIS-100 is a can be a challenging puzzle game, even for those that have some programming experience. I think this game (while not a perfect model for any esiting assembly language) is a beautiful way to get into the mindset that makes programming easier (to plan and to visualize). The limitations of the instruction set used for solving each program puzzle can be frustrating, but it's a tantalizing frustration (Ex: I know how to solve this problem in C; how can I adapt what I know there into the patterns for doing things here?). I found the game highly rewarding with the open-endedness of the puzzles.

My first solutions to each of the puzzle tended to be jury-rigged together. They work, but I can make it better. I can try to make it take fewer cycles (faster) to finish testing the instructions. I can consolidate the code so it uses fewer of the nodes MOV-ing data back and forth. I can work towards a solution that needs fewer lines of code to have a solution.  Each of these “execution nodes” holds no more than 15 lines of instructions. There were many times I could’ve solved a problem easier if I had 16 lines; it forced me to think at the problem from a different perspective. I would not describe this as an easy puzzle game. It is simple, but not easy.

This game required from me:
[list]
[*]Logical A→B→C thought progressions
[*]Understanding how to modularize a problem into separable steps that can be tested individually
[*]Patience and diligence to deal with my own mistakes (a program will only do as instructed and I caused it to not work)
[*]Creativity with instructions that behaved unlike stuff I was familiar with
[/list]

Overall, my playtime took under 35 hours to get a working solution to each of the 47 puzzles. Interspaced in that were 40ish hours for trying to improve some of my solutions. Recently this year, I’ve taken a personal challenge at getting “UNCONDITIONAL” (like the namesake achievement) solutions to all the puzzles. I’ve already done so the first 25 puzzles (nightmare difficulty for the SEQUENCE SORTER puzzle).

If you get this game, may you come to learn the beauty of JRO and the profane magic of JRO ANY.

37708932.review:
I grew up in the 80s with the early home computers, and my fondest memories of those days were of prying open bits and pieces and finding out how things worked, as well as how things COULD work if you were just willing to subvert the designer's original intent.  Code hacking was just part of the computing experience in 1985.

I do miss those days, because you can't really do that anymore with modern computers.  They're too complex, too locked down.  So when I stumbled over this little game, it intrigued me.  And then it frustrated me.  And then it enraged me.   And then I realized I was totally addicted, and in many ways transported back to being 14 years old.  

You have to be fond of puzzle games like this.  But if you are, this is awesome.

36147121.review:
As a Programmer, who once used assembler: Not recommended 
(I only finished about 60% of the first page suspecting there is more like in Infinifactory)

The game is a good idea, i thought it would be a fun return to my assembler days. But to make it more gamy a view limitations are imposed:
1. the only accessable storage beeing acc, meaning you can only save in one "slot/variable/addressable space". This is mitigated because you actually have multiple cors "nodes" with each one having a acc.
2. communikation between nodes is tiresome because non blocking operations are missing.+The Instruction set is super minimal. Inifinifactory had a similar problem in my eyes: the logic was just to limiting.
3. code is not reusable, and each node can only sore about 20 lines of code -> combined with the small storage and small instructon set this is just infuriating to me. You have a solution in mind but miss 2 lines to complete it.... now you need to start from scratch. Inifinifactory did not have that start from scratch problem. 

The "IDE" functionality is also not as nice as i expected. No autocompletion, code navigation also not as great as Intellij ;)

What I like about this game is that they tried. I respect Zach Barth thinking of "new" ideas for engineers. (Hint: If you like his games you should be an engineer:)

Maybe "Shenzhen IO" adresses those Issues of mine. I hav not tied it yet. Or learinig swift could be fun with apples playgrounds (heard nice stuff of it)... but i have no IOs devices. Or invest in a small raspberryPi with breadboard and led kit.

36091936.review:
Looking into TIS-100 for two hours, and it's pretty obvious what kind of game it is and what to expect from it. 

Foremost, its obviously trying to inspire that retro-hardship software development was in the past, and this is another one that gets close to hitting the old software terminal nostaglia. An interesting idea is introducing a basic cross-platform assembly syntax, despite being more limited then assembly. Where in assembly you have a few registeries you can interact with and you're responsible for all the memory you mess with, here you get one accessable registry to save and read from, and one inaccessable one you can save and swap to. That's per node (ignoring the stack nodes), which is a limited interface that represents seperated code execution.

For the less tech inclined, this means the puzzles are about using limited resources to design a solution, and the game's mechanics only really get an addition once as far as I see, (I'm unsure but there might be graphical problems too) and it has to be a robust one, a hacked together one designed for the current input you see would fail the testing system. I'm less inclined to call it problem solving game so far because the solutions do appear to have an optimal design, and while technically you're scope of design is close enough to unlimited to qualify for problem solving and there is no strictly garunteed optimal design in that way, the solutions are most times going to only have one optimal design and then strictly less optimal design. But that's ignorable unless you're a 100% obessesive completionist, to most it will be more akin to programming style problem solving. For those who aren't software developers or into lower level code, this game will have a higher learning curve, and having no skills in programming at all, I'd definitely think its a extremely steep cliff, this game does not really guide you and has no tutorial, you're using a reference manual the whole time to deduce the purpose of everything. For those of us used to code documentation, its a quick 5 or less minutes to get started, for everyone else, it will most definitely be longer then 15 to get setup.

And for everything else:

The puzzles are pretty deep for only having three different types of interfaces. (one of which just discards values)

You get stack machines later, where you can push values to the top and take values off the top. Would've been nice to have seen other types of IO interfaces in the game, but the current concept has a nice simplistic idea. And I suppose is easy to wrap your head around

There is the ability to mess with pixels in the executing code, so you can draw small images.

You can create your own puzzles however it only has you designating input values, output values, and the layout of interfaces, nothing specifically new can be added. Though you can pretty easily share the puzzles around.

You can mess with a no objective sandbox where you can input values and get output values, though you have to get through a good few puzzles to get anything interesting.

There is also the ability to copy programs if you did something like say create a basic start framework.

Other then that, the game is very simple and in my opinion is definitely worth the seven bucks, and would be nice to be expanded upon much further in the future somehow. (It likely won't but it definitely is an idea that could be taken much further.

36067445.review:
(まだ途中ですが面白いのでオススメ)

あなたはTIS-100という古いマシーンを中古で手に入れましたが、起動しようとするとエラーで止まってしまいます。
デバッガは立ち上がるようなので、付属していたリファレンスのコピーを元に何とか動かしてやろうという体のゲームです。
リファレンスのコピーには元の持ち主のメモのほか、一通の手紙が重ねて印刷してあります。

[quote=] [i]Mへ
　Randyおじさんが急死した衝撃から未だに立ち直ることができません。
　精一杯のことをしながら審査官が結論を出すのを待っているところです。
　私の気持ちはあの人のことでいっぱいです。特に、コンピュータについて。もちろんガレージであれを見たときからずっと、私にとっては迷惑ながらくただったのだけれど。こんど写真を送ります。

　とにかく、あの人が亡くなったときに机の上にあったものです。あなたならあの人が何をしていたのかわかると思います。
　あの人ならきっと、誰かがやりかけていたことを知りたがったと思うから。

愛を込めて、
Drisおばさんより[/i]
[/quote]

ゲームは1つ以上のINから入ってくる入力を受けて、指定された条件でOUTに出す、というルールのロジックパズルです。
ここだけ見ると同メーカーのSpaceChemに似ていますが、こっちは入力値の加工をアセンブラに似たルールのプログラムで行います。
ルールは前述したリファレンスが付属しているので、最初からすべての命令が使えます。
プログラムというと凄く難しそうですが、使える命令が書いてあるのは数ページだけです。アセンブラなので覚えることも少なく、この手の表現が気に入るならば全く問題なくプレイできるはずです。
なお、ステージのクリア条件は左上の箱の中に書かれています。


パズルを解くたびにTIS-100の修理が進んでいくといった具合ですが、進めていくとメモリの中に焼き付けられたいくつかのメッセージが発見できます。
どうやらこのコンピュータは人づてに渡り続けていたようで、かつて何人も解析を試みたことがあるようです。
IBMやモトローラの技術者の助けを借りてみたひとも居たようですが、今ここにあると言うことは誰もうまくやることができなかったのでしょう。

メッセージの中にはRandy氏のものと思われるものも散見され、コンピュータの由来やRandy氏に何があったのか、といったミステリーも進行するのかもしれません。
先を進めるのが楽しみです。

オススメ

35622054.review:
Oh yes!

TIS-100 is a game where you get to program a parallel computing system in an assembly language syntax. The instruction set is easy to learn as there are only a handful of instructions. I won't say anything about the story in the game but each puzzle has a specification for what your program should do. You read from n inputs and write to m outputs. The output is tested in four runs to check if you wrote a program that appears to behave correctly. There's also a few sandbox modes where you can play around with stacks, put pixels on the screen and get rudimentary input from a console. Upon solving a puzzle you get score in three categories. The number of instructions you used, the number of nodes you used and the number of clock cycles it took to complete the task. You'll see a histogram of global scores to compare how you've done and friends will have their best scores listed numerically.

Some puzzles have good replayability as they are hard to optimize. Others are quite simple and serve no replayability at all. On reddit there's a listing of records in four categories. Some of them just seem insane to beat. Sure, you might have got the optimal clock cycles down, but can you reduce the number of nodes and instructions while still keeping up with the clock cycles?

Finally, there's also a possibility to write your own puzzles although there is no convenient way to share them with the world. 

If there's anything I dislike with the game, well... For sandbox mode, I would really have enjoyed being able to configure so that there could be more nodes, or more instructions per node. I get it, it's about optimization and scarce resources, but it would also be fun to roam around a bit in a creative fashion. But other than that, I don't really have anything to complain about. For a programming puzzle game, it's great!

35565696.review:
Inheriting your late uncles computer, your left to figure out how it works. The only thing to help you is an obscure manual which you can print out in PDF or save to your tablet / phone for reference. 

TIS-100 is not just a tough nut to crack, its a nut, sealed inside a lead box, inside a safe which is guarded by techno dinosaurs armed with rocket launchers. By the time you actually solve one of the puzzles you will be left wondering why you didn't just pop down the corner shop and buy a bag of nuts and save yourself all the stress. As the rewards for completing a puzzle are lackluster at best. The difficulty level of this game (if one can call it such) is ridiculous and unforgiving in its brutality on the gamers sense of self worth. You will either find these puzzle relatively straight forward or spend hours hitting your head against the keyboard, begging for a merciful death. Unlike other puzzle games, TIS-100 has only one difficulty mode which seems to be its charm and also it's curse. Programmers, logical thinkers will find this game fun and addictive, where as your casual gamer will likely come away wonder what all the fuss was about. The interface is basic and rudimentary, complimenting the vintage computer theme of the game, however I would have liked to have seen some effort taken to pull in the casual gamer. As it stands this game is like Marmite, you’ll either love it to bits or be wiping your tongue on the living room carpet, desperately trying to get rid of the bitter after taste.

35508033.review:
This game has a very intense learning curve, so I imagine most players will be frustrated trying to get the hang of it.  That said, if you want a nice set of optimization challenges relating to information flow, this is a fantastic game to pick up.  It also serves as a good framework for building intuition about parallelized processes in the real world.

The game is played via a very constrained programming language, on a grid of nodes which each can only hold a loop of up to 15 instructions, and two values.  Nodes run in parallel, values are passed from node to node, input is converted to output, and if you match their expected output on all 4 tests you have succeeded in that challenge.

The game has a histogram for every challenge showing the best scores across all players in each category: cycles, nodes, and instructions.  There is typically a tradeoff, to use fewer cycles to generate the output you add more instructions across more nodes, and so on.

My favorite aspect of the game is the skill ceiling.  The subreddit /r/tis100 holds leaderboards that have been updated regularly since the game's inception, and people are still finding ways to make the solutions faster, more compact or more elegant.  With such a limited set of operations, the fact that there are still tricks to find and use can come as a surprise.  But it speaks well to the design of the challenges - there is just enough complexity that obvious solutions, when they even exist, don't even turn out to be the best ones.

35465946.review:
Be aware what you're getting into.  Some people would say this barely qualifies as a game.

TIS-100 is a series of programming challenges using a deliberately limited interface and assembly language.  You will find yourself wishing for the ability to declare another variable or write a simple for loop.

Story elements are minimal--a short, unrelated diary entry is present in each puzzle, and that's it.  Don't expect to uncover a mystery naturally.

People unfamiliar with programming will likely have an extremely difficult time.  People familiar with programming have more productive things they could be doing in languages that don't go out of their way to be as user-unfriendly as possible.

35392579.review:
먼저 밝히자면 필자(컴공 아니다)는 대학때 전공으로 수치해석 배우면서 c언어를 if문 정도까지 배운게 다다. 사실상 코딩 경험 없고 프로그래밍 문외한이라고 봐도 된다(수치해석 시간에도 코딩하는 조별과제는 잘하는 친구가 혼자서 하드캐리했다)

본 게임은 흔히 다루지 않는 어셈블리를 게임화시킨 것으로서 c언어도 제대륻 배운적이 없는데 컴공도 다룰일이 없는 어셈블리게임을 과연 할 수 있을까 걱정이 많았다. 그러나 어셈블리 명령어 중 극히 일부만을 사용해서 총 외워야될 명령어가 20개 정도 밖에 안 되고 이것들 가지고 머리써서 코딩하면 되기 때문에 그렇게 진지한 코딩문제는 아니라고 볼 수 있다. 그러나 오히려 이것은 코딩에 큰 제약이 되어 괴롭히게 된다.

알고리즘을 고안해냈다고 끝이 아니라 모듈당 15줄로 제한된 코딩공간과 모듈당 두개의 임시기억소자를 이용해야하기 때문에 대다수 해법을 찾아내도 쓰레기통으로 직행했다. 그리고 사용할 수 있는 명령어가 20개 남짓정도 되는데, 이마저도 제한된 명령어 만으로 해결을 봐야해서 더 어렵게 만드는 제약이 된다.

그냥 알고리즘을 고안하는것도 버거운데 최적화까지 동시에 고려하면서 몇개 되지 않는 명령어 만으로 해결을 해야해서 코딩 문외한인 나로서는 일단 여기까지만 하도록 한다. 수많은 제약에 질려버려서 딱히 더 풀고 싶지 않다. 어떻게 풀어낸 사람들 보면 대단하다는 생각은 들지만 부럽지는 않다. 마치 서커스단을 보면서 신기하긴 하나 나도 딱히 저런 기예를 하고싶진 않은 것과 같다랄까.

30시간 넘게 즐거웠다. 공략없이 내 머리로만 해보려고 했으나 20문제 중 5문제는 클리어하지 못했다. 차라리 진짜 코딩을 배우는게 나을 것 같다.
 
여튼 가급적 프로그래밍에 문외한이면 사지마라. 튜토리얼이 없다시피해서 스테이지1부터 막힐 수 있다. 첨부된 메뉴얼이 있으나 명령어 설명위주이고, 활용에 대한 예제문제가 없기 때문에 봐도 큰 도움이 안 된다. 처음이면 그냥 위키나 블로그에 있는 입문자를 위한 명령어 해설이나 팁들을 보고 시작해라. 원래부터 기본베이스로 알고 시작해야 하는 실전형 게임이다. 즉 게임을 해보기도 전에 게임에 대한 배경지식이 기본으로 있어야 하는 모순적인 게임이다. 필자는 뭣모르고 메뉴얼 보면서 독학하다가 시간을 너무 버렸다.

왠지 이 게임에 대해 비추하는 것 같지만, 일반인에게 비추하는거고, 컴공이시거나 프로그래밍 어느정도 하시는데 어셈블리는 접한적이 없는사람에게는 기초를 배우는데 큰 도움이 될것 같다. 그리고 어찌됐든 재밋게 놀았고 가격도 싸서 추천한다.

35172775.review:
SpaceChem is one of my favorite games, and I have 85 hours of playtime on it. So it was a no-brainer to buy TIS-100, and I was excited to try it out.

I'm not dissappointed I bought it (supporting ZachTronics), but I didn't love this game the way I fell in love with SpaceChem. Probable reasons:
- It's less elegant. The comands are real-life assembly commands -- not desiged for simplicity or usability.
- It's less visual. This means that debugging is harder, and watching your program run isn't as satisfying.
- It doesn't help you learn the mechanics. Instead, you are given a weblink to a pdf "manual" with instructions, and are just expected to read through it. Reading the manual rather feels like completing tedious assigned homework.

The bottom line: if you don't particularly like programming in assembly, you may not particularly like this game.

王小波说：“我理解你的孤岛。是要熬时间，所以我要带一本能熬人的书，比如《吉米多维奇数学分析习题集》。”

愚以为，本作就是经得起熬的一个游戏作品。熬并非贬义词，非指煎熬，而是一种痛苦而又享受的欢愉。它就像爱一个使我们怀疑的女子，一个妩媚的女子，无恒，不驯，恣肆，允诺同时抗拒，羞怯而又嘲讽，同情却又诱惑，冲动但又苦涩，因而更具魅力。她使得你受苦，可是你又怎会不愿意为她而受苦呢？所以受苦成为了一种快乐。她诚然有她的罪恶，可是当她自道恶毒时，她尤为迷人。你也许会恨她，而当你恨她的时候，你其实也最爱她。所以本作的主旨乃是苦中作乐，熬出品味，人生方得以拨云见日。

34892028.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

TIS-100 is a puzzle game were you have to implement programs using an assembly like language. This game will probably be easier for software developers but it's still just a glorified puzzle. There are just a few instructions that are easy to understand. The real challenge is using the few instructions to make complex programs. If you're up to such a challenge this is a game for you.

+ Interesting concept
+ Convincing manual and system
+ Hard puzzles even for programmers
+ Decent debug tools

[h1]Review[/h1]

In TIS-100 you start by being given an intimidating instruction manual that explains how to program in the made up assembly language, but fear not, you only really need to memorize some instructions and perhaps read the examples. The instruction manual and operating system are very convincing and makes you wonder if such a machine existed in real life. Unfortunately the computer never existed.

The computer is comprised of nodes and each nodes has two registers that can store a number. You can copy the value of your primary register to other nodes and often you have to because the memory is very limited. In fact lack of memory is one of the major challenges of this game. The other major challenge is that you only have a few instructions that can only be executed in your first register. For example, you cannot compare two values directly. You can only compare your primary register with zero. To top it all most instructions such as set, add or subtract only work in the primary register; the secondary register can only copy the value from the primary register or swap values with each other. It's a hard game even for software developers such as myself. A very interesting and unique concept.

The instruction manual and the puzzles themselves might be hard to grasp for someone who never touched a programming language but perhaps that's for the best so that beginners have more of an authentic experience of what was programming in the early days. Having a tutorial would probably ruin the experience and the satisfaction of having solved a puzzle. Sometimes the specification itself is hard to understand but that's also one of the difficulties of real life programming. That said you will learn some assembly but you should see it as more of a very challenging puzzle.

34543324.review:
This certainly isn't an easy game, but it's hugely satisfying when you spend hours breaking a problem down, debugging, realising mistakes in your logic, and can finally see your program spin to life and solve some (eventually very complex!) problems, using nothing more than the simple building blocks. The score histograms give you a reason to come back and optimise your solutions, giving the game some replay value. There isn't much story, but I don't think that this is necessarily a bad thing - trying to shoehorn more story elements, unless done cleverly, might get in the way of the excellent puzzling experience. It would have been interesting to have higher-level computing tasks, built up from the lower-level modules which you've developed at earlier stages in the game, but I can't blame the developers from restricting the scope of the game to keep things simpler. 

This game certainly won't be for everyone, but if programming/logic challenges are your thing, I can't recommend this game highly enough.

33861593.review:
Disclaimer:  I'm a chemistry major.  My experience with programming is next to none, apart from reading up on SNES hardware/65816 assembly for like a week straight, locked in my dorm room and on the verge of despair.  (Long story.)

TIS-100 is the hardest game I have ever played, full stop.  I have never felt more like a moron than I do while playing this game, a feeling only briefly relieved at the moment when I solve a puzzle, only to return once I close out the following puzzle without writing a single instruction.  I might only have three hours in this game, but I've spent more than three times as much thinking about this game, both about it's solutions and it's meaning.  And I've only managed to come close to a solution to the latter.

This is not a puzzle game, exactly.  I feel like this is closer to a sim game, specifically about the life of a 1960's/1970's programmer, before ISAs became even close to something considered "standard".  This isn't exactly about learning a programming language as it is about being given a piece of proprietary hardware you've never seen before and a poorly detailed manual and being asked to magically figure it out for yourself.  I don't think I've ever seen a "puzzle" game with such a dedication to the experience its game creates within the player, the kind of thing only possible within an interactive medium like this, and the more I think about it, the more it could only be intentional.  

The manual is pdf made to look like a stapled together handbook.  It is the best manual for a game I have seen in about a decade, and also the least effective manual I have ever seen at actually teaching the player how to play the game; it offers a bare explanation of what the various opcodes and registers do, but absolutely no information on how they should be used.  Inside you will find occasional highlights and notes in pen from the previous owner, absolutely none of which are helpful in furthering your understanding of the language.

The thing is, the bad manual is part of the experience.  If this game had a good manual or tutorial, it would just be a game about assembly language, probably a good one at that, but there's nothing that quite compares to the bleak stare of a white-text-on-black display and a useless paper manual in creating a feeling of utter helplessness.

And just solving the puzzle isn't enough, either.  TIS-100 will then compare your solution to those of your friends to show you how unoptimized your code is, and you can go online and see people who have done it even better, or look in the achievements to see even more ridiculous challenges.  There is an achievement for programming a signal comparator (run the inputs through a signum function and then write a binary output to three nodes depending on the sign of the output) without using conditional jump instructions.  I feel stupefied by the thought that this is even possible.

I don't think I'll ever finish this game, but I know for certain I won't forget it.  Maybe I'll come back to it later, but I get the feeling somehow that this game is greater than me, and it's probably greater than you, too.  It's too complex to be simplified and too complex to be accessible, but it's worth your money and time if you think you might be interested.

32461630.review:
TIS-100 is a good programming game that provides plenty of puzzles that are both challenging and satisfying to complete.

     The gameplay is relatively simple.  You're given a list of incomplete programs (puzzles) and you select whichever one you want to work on.  You're then given a set of instructions, a list providing one or more inputs, and a list showing you what the output(s) should be.  So you always know what you're trying to achieve and you know what any given input should be when it reaches the output.  The programs consist of 12 separate nodes which you can enter instructions into.  Every puzzle has 1 or more nodes that have some sort of “communication failure” message in them which simply renders that node unusable and forces you to work around them.  You also must work around the facts that: 1.  You're limited to 15 total commands per node and 2.  Commands you can enter into the nodes are intentionally not very sophisticated.  There are only 13 total commands in the game and they're broken down into 4 categories.  1.  Moving numbers from one node to another  2. Saving/Swapping memory  3. Basic math (Only add, subtract, swapping positive/negative sign) 4. Split path/jump commands (Do this set of instructions if the number is positive, do this set of instructions if the number is negative, do this set of instructions if the number is 0.)  Once you've designed your program how you like, you hit the run button and the game runs the inputs through your program until they reach the output.  If the input numbers that reach the output have been altered to match up to list that you were given at the start then you complete the program.  If there is an error somewhere, you'll have to note where the error occurs and pause your program while it's running at a point before the error.  You can then press the “Step” button which allows you to view your commands running one 'tick' at a time.  You can then use this to follow an input, see which node it enters that causes the problem, and then attempt to fix the problem.

     So the game is pretty user friendly.  Pressing escape brings up the option to open up the manual for the “TIS-100” and provides you with some flavor text as though it's an actual manual for an actual machine.  It gives you a description of the nodes as well as a list of all the commands and examples of how to use them.  There's also some other info in there on stuff that will show up later in the game in puzzles such as “Stack nodes” or how to make your outputs display color.  You can also press F1 while in a program to bring up a list of all the commands and references to what they do.  The first row of 5 puzzles are mostly tutorial puzzles meant to slowly introduce you to the basic concepts.  The first puzzle is just moving numbers around, and half of it is already filled in to show you exactly how to enter commands.  The second introduces addition.  The third introduces subtraction and splitting the path of your number.  The fourth and fifth involve needing to use jump commands.  The game gets more difficult from there on out.  You will almost always have access to multiple incomplete programs, so if you ever get stuck on one, you can save your progress, quit out and work on another program.

     Pros:  There are 22 puzzles in the “TIS-100 segment map” as well as 25 user created puzzles includes in the “TIS-NET directory”.  At around 20 hours of actual gameplay, I'd only completed 23/47 total puzzles, so you'll get plenty out of this game if you enjoy it.  Once you've completed a couple puzzles, remembered that F1 is your friend, and are familiar with the basic commands, the game is very simple to play.  The hard part isn't in fighting the controls but in figuring out a basic gameplan, where you screwed up, and if/how you can fix it.  It's fairly easy to track down your errors and see what's causing them.  Each program contains a node with an error message that when clicked  provides flavor text for some sort of an attempt at a plot/story.  Puzzles start out simple enough to familiarize you with the basic concepts and grow more difficult and devious from there.  Completing many of the later puzzles is very satisfying, especially when you open up one you've been having trouble with and the solution suddenly comes to you.

     The cons.  There's not much here other than programming puzzles.  There's no real plot or story to the game.  The interface is pretty barebones and bland.  There aren't any characters or dialogue.  There's no music.  It would've been nice if they included a reference for the color puzzles when you press F1, but having to open up the manual to reference them isn't a big deal.

     Not much more to say.  It's a good game to sit down for 30-60 minutes and rack your brain over a puzzle. If you're looking for a puzzle game with plot/story, characters, and dialogue, then you should avoid this game.  TIS-100 won't be for everyone but for those who enjoy, you'll get plenty of time out of it even if you only complete half the puzzles.  Damn you 'Sequence Sorter'.

32331153.review:
A fun, challenging programming game, with some smart design decisions (e.g., code must literally fit in the boxes). There is enough story to keep things interesting without getting in the way, and enough challenge to make the 100% completion feel earned.

The sort of thinking required reminds me of Manufactoria -- interesting resource constraints give you an excuse to use horrific but strangely elegant algorithms. And, perhaps moreso than Manufactoria, progression involves discovering and refining useful primitives. The way I was using the TIS when I completed the game was decidely more elegant, quirkier, and hackier than during the first few puzzles.

For me, Spacechem felt like work, while this feels like fun.

NOTE: Like most puzzle games, my playtime reflects a lot of having the game running while doing other things.

31292397.review:
Disclaimer: There's not necessarily 346 hours of content. I just sometimes forget to shut down the game and/or like to watch some of my solutions more than once. Having said that, this game WILL keep you busy for a while.

So I just finished 100% completion of this game, and figured I'd finally levy my thoughts on it in a review. So first off: I love this game. Sure, the game may tell you flat out what you're SUPPOSED to do (except in the hidden puzzle - RTFM to find it), but it's up to you to take those specifications and figure out how to make them a reality in practice. Trust me when I say this: If you don't even have a basic idea of how to approach your problem you're going to struggle to complete it.

Of course, even if you THINK you have a great idea for how to get a puzzle to complete, you still have to actually write it out and test it. More often than not, there will be a flaw in your thinking or coding that will make your approach not quite work. Your goal of course is to try to correct that flaw, which will more often than not require using breakpoints and stepping. While you may be able to sometimes fix a problem, other times you will make things worse or even run into command space issues. There's only one thing I can say about this: There's no shame whatsoever in deleting a program, and coming back to it later. I've done that more than I care to admit. Once you do eventually solve it it'll feel amazing, and you might even think of new ways to solve it by tackling another problem!

Tl;dr: This game is hard. Even when you think you've got something figured out you might not, and you have to consider whether you want to try to tweak your solution idea or abandon it. In the end though, resolving a problem is one of the most satisfying feelings you can have, especially when it provides inspiration for another problem.

[b][i]"REPAIR THE TIS-100"[/i][/b]

Alright, I will be absolutely honest, I have clearly no single idea what I've done in this game, how I've done it and how friends who helped me have done it and certainly I've no idea what is this game about. 

Rock Paper Shotgun said that if you're able to solve most of these puzzles, you're ready to code. And if that's the case and I'm assuming it is, then big shoutout goes to Zachtronics. And it's not even single s/o. Zach also made SpaceChem, don't forget that. And obviously Tessellated Intelligence System.

Game offers you over 20 puzzles to solve, it lets you desing your own stuff and own games within TIS-100 game, and even the manual this game have has that good old 80s vibe. That's real talk.

And how long will this game lasts for you? Well, the span is really really subjective. Some dudes can do it within 5 hours, some 10 and some 25 and well some over 50. It all depends on knowledge. With assistance of some of my friends (oh boy, it was 24/7 online service :D) I was able to finish it in 12 hours.

I'm honest guy so, this game was not really fun for me at all. Game is popping awesome. I won't leave numerical rating, but I definitely do recommend it to coders and people out there who knows what they are doing.

30846744.review:
"It's the assembly language programming game you never asked for!" -Zachtronics

You have no idea how right you are.

The game provides challenging assembly programming language puzzles, and they can certainly be satisfying when you finally figure out how to solve them. Unfortunately, there are multiple problems with it:

-It is difficult to get into without assembly coding experience. It lacks any kind of tutorial, instead giving you a manual that, while introducing you to the commands that you'll be using, doesn't really explain how to use them. Even with my (small amount of) coding experience, I had alot of trouble figuring out what I was actually supposed to be doing with these commands

-The language and architecture used in the game is outdated and doesn't fit with the goal of these puzzles. While this game could teach you to code if you were living in the 80s or 90s, it would barely help you today. The computer that the game simulates doesn't take advantage of modern processing improvements (The game even mentions the USSR as if it still existed in the timeframe of the game-given how the game's computer operates, that's easy to believe.). Additionally, the game asks you to do things which the language was seemingly not made to do (for example: some puzzles ask you to multiply or divide, but the language only has add and subtract commands. Also, you might be asked to compare numbers or change the output based on a condition, which, again, the language doesn't have a command for). It feels like trying to build a house by stacking rocks- you'll get there eventually, but it'll be slow, and the thing's gonna fall over at least a few times before you get there.


tl;dr: While the game tries to turn assembly coding into a challenging and potentially educational puzzle, the outdated architecture and clunky language ruins the fun, assuming you understand the coding enough to actually have fun in the first place.

We're in the 21st century now, game. This isn't what coding is like.

30827844.review:
What can I say about this other than that it is absolutely brilliant?

I bought this after listening to Zach Barth's interview on The Amp Hour. The sales pitch was a little odd, and I was skeptical and first, but I am HOOKED. The game is fairly short (only 20 puzzles) but finishing the levels is only the beginning: you will drive yourself nuts trying to squeeze out those last few cycles. The transputer architecture lets you try totally different approaches to problems architecturally, instead of just obsessing and polishing over a single piece of code.

This game will make you laugh, cry, punch the air, headbutt your desk. You may not see your family or friends for days. Essentially a much condensed form of the programming experience. If you're skeptical, give it a try. What's the worst that could happen?

30482632.review:
There are two parts to this review. One for people with no coding experience at all, and those who have coded, even at a basic level, in Assembly.

To the people who have never coded:

This game will be a little challenging at first. You may sit and be stuck at the first one for a while, but if you keep at it youll start to get the hang of it and get into the swing of this language. The benefit is this is a simple language once you understand it, so it's a good intro to assembly level coding and how it functions on a fundamental level.

If youre not tech savy at all, I might not reccomend the game to you, however I am a firm believer that anyone can code given enough time and practice. 

All in all, from a standpoint of a person with no background in programming, I think this is a good buy, especially on sale. 

To the people with coding background:

If you're like me, and are either studying Computer Science in college, or are self taught, or have decent experience in real world applications, this game might be a little on the easy side. Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed it completely and would buy it again. However by about the 3rd puzzle I had the general system down and was able to have pretty decently optimized programs without much effort. Now I dont know how the rest of the game will be, but I got pretty far in one 2 hour session (I left my PC on overnight so thats why I have 24 hrs).

If you are somoene who codes assembly daily, you may find this too easy. I havent coded Assembly in months, so it was refreshing and relaxing to me to pick it up and practice a little. That may not be the case for you.

Still, I think its worth a go. At $7 thats not too bad, and if its on sale its a no brainer.

The Tessellated Intelligence Systems 100 model is, by and large, one of the most complex computers I will ever use. It's multi-node structure is confusing, and for an assembly computer it proves to be applicable in only buisness use, not the home use.

This game really challenges you to understand where your mistakes are, and how to work with the system given to you. It's actually realy enjoyable once you realize that this game was supposed to originally be a mini-game for another project; they scrapped that game and, since they already wrote out almost all of the programming for the mini-game, they ran with it to make it a whole game on its own.

The one gripe I have is that the lore of this game, oh dear god the lore, it makes me WANT to find out how to get those other textes it talks about in its manual (Dear god, if you don't have the FREE manual provided in the source folder printed or written down, this game would be 6000X harder); but it all serves to just make this game all the more real feeling as you play it.

I have yet to play it all the way to its finish, but I have played many good hours into this game, and will play many more into it; good job Zachtronics, keep being awesome.

30064339.review:
EXCELLENT in it's simplicity. This 'game' seems a lot more complicated than it is. While you are basically learning Assembly programming (which is the best part of this. it's practical learning), Assembly's concepts are -extremely- simple. I'm talking concepts like basic addition and subtraction. If you can do those two things, you CAN underatand this game. It comes with a very elegantly written fourteen page manual that tells you everything you need to know plus a little bit of flavor text to get you into the narrative. The main difference between actual Assembly and this 'game' is that the fictional computer you're using basically has several different CPUs or "nodes" that can each be programmed seperately and are usually capable of talking to each other. There are always multiple ways of solving a problem. You can make it as hard or as easy on yourself as you want. There are achievements for figuring out how to optimize your code in clever ways. You can, however, beat this game ignoring all of that. To top it off, the game comes with a 'sandbox' mode that allows you to create any program you want without the limitations of the main puzzles. There is even a mode that allows you to create your own puzzles to challenge other people. A very complete package that includes everything you could want but never gets in your way. 

If you have any interest in computers or programming what-so-ever and also enjoy 'puzzle games', I HIGHLY reccomend that you give this a try. It's very novel, well priced, very fun, and will teach you valuable real-life programming concepts.

This programmer/puzzle game quite obviously isn't for everyone, and to be honest I thought it looked way too complicated the first time I saw it. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was easier to get into than I had expected, and having solved about 10 of the puzzles I'm really beginning to get into the mindset. Meanwhile, things are getting more complicated ofcourse, and to be honest I don't expect to be able to solve them all. This doesn't even matter, because I'm still having fun trying to sort things out. 

The simulated architecture is ofcourse completely unrealistic, nothing like this exists in the real world. For instance, there is only one proper register per "tile", no actual RAM and ridiculously limited space for program code. (Think in terms of BYTES, not kilobytes) On the other hand, all read/write operations are blocking so timing is very intuitive, and the game interface lets you see exactly what is going on at all times as you run your program one step at a time if you want.

The game comes with documentation in the form of a PDF file, this is a MUST READ but I found it to be exceptionally well written as an introduction and reference, with just enough example code to get you started.  Or you could just use YouTube if you're so inclined.

Basically, if you ever did any sort of computer programming, you will probably have no trouble getting into this game.

29955812.review:
So I got this game in a humble bundle.  I didn't think much of it, but thought the name sounded cool.   I mean it was a staff pick, so who knows what I'm going to get. 

Then I played it.  OH WOW!  This game reminds me of another game called spacechem, and now that I'm writing this review, I can see on the page that it was written by the same guy, and it really feels like that. 

The entire game is about coding.  You work on a microprocessor and have a number of tasks to complete, and to be honest, this isn't a game where you pretend to code, or you use a very fake coding language.  No, if you play this game and you beat it, you HAVE programmed and you have used assembly, it's as simple as that.   This is a game, but at the same time, this is essentially the same thing as real coding (only it's a bit harder on this game for artificial constraints). 

To play the game you get a manual (which you really should look at) and an assignment.  It can be as simple as take in two variables and add them together.  Or as complex as multiply them together.... and yes multiplying the values is significantly harder than adding them.   You also get up to 12 processors that are connected through ports.  They can read in information, operate on it and push that information to another port (or the same one). 

The complexity comes in that each processor has a limited number of operations you can record on it.  There's some beautiful control codes (jumps, labels and the rest) but rather than give you unlimited space ( which could make the multiplication simple) you have about 10 operations (maybe a little more) and that's it. Then the code loops.  You can use any number of available processors (sometimes there's small limitations, but you always have more than enough) but trying to make the computer do exactly as the tasks says is challenging. 

There's a few other wrinkles.  Each processor is given ONE register.. (and that my dear friends is why multiplication is a nightmare. )

So overall how is it?  Well I'm a programmer, I love programming, and I am absolutely in love with this game.  It's not for everyone but it's a BOTH a great introduction to REAL assembly, and a fantastic game.  It's definitely not for everyone, but I can't praise this game highly enough.   I don't know if everyone will fall in love with this game, but if you have played spacechem before and want something a little harder, give this a shot.  If you haven't played spacechem and don't know if you'll enjoy programming, I'd recommend Spacechem only because it's a little more accessible, however both games are excellent and I highly recommend them.

I received this game as a gift from a friend off my wishlist, and it is a tremendously fun game for computer programmers to challenge their logic skills on a very minimalistic computer simulation.  I've done machine code and assembler programming since the mid 1980s on real hardware and quite frankly it is a dying art with all of the modern high level languages floating about.  I haven't done much low level code for a few years now and it was something I always enjoyed.  While TIS-100 is nowhere remotely near what you can do on a real processor, it is immensely fun to solve its puzzles - specifically because of the severe limitations of the processor.  It also challenges the mind to think in terms of parallelization to reduce the cycle count for a better score on many puzzles.

Non-programmers probably wont get much further than solving 3-4 of the most basic puzzles, however if you're a computer programmer who loves solving coding and/or logic puzzles, then this is the game for you.

28650266.review:
As disclosure, I've programmed since I was very young.

This game is quite a fun programming puzzle and also a very kind introduction to assembly programming. You don't need any experience to enjoy the puzzles because the system is very simple and intuitive! The game runs smooth, no crashes, and the graphics are just right to evoke the experience of using early GUI systems. 

There's a small story to accompany the system, which you unlock as you progress through the game, as well as a few collectables. For those new to programming, you will spend a few hours thinking about each puzzle and debugging your solutions, but you will find it very rewarding as you acquire mastery.

For those who've programmed before, you'll find many of the puzzles simple, though you may sometimes struggle to fit logic into each cell; it's very difficult to have one cell do all the work, so don't be afraid to have cells communicate with eachother!

For $8, this game is well-priced and well-made, along with accompanying sandboxes and a challenge creator. The TIS-100 is a great programming toy and puzzle, although experienced programmers will need only ~10 hours of playtime to beat the game.

That said, programming is not for everybody. You'll spend a lot of time on each puzzle and the only reward you will get is seeing things working as intended. In fact, far more often you'll be frustrated that things *aren't* working. Nonetheless, this game captures the fun and challenge of programming with a much lower barrier to entry than normal! 

I highly recommend this game as a diversion that may eventually consume your time at school and work while you feverishly try to design a solution for segments you've been stumped on. If you know somebody with a clever mind and a bit of patience, this game is a great gift. 

For the developer:
Well done, and although the story was a bit cliche, the game itself is solid design. Keep it up!

28623645.review:
A nice little problem-solving game. Features a fictional computer with a very simplistic architecture and minimal instruction set, so it should be easy for novices and perhaps even non-programmers to catch on.

No prior knowledge of any assembly language is necessary, though some understanding of how computers work may be beneficial. Though I already had experience writing assembly as a hobby, I can definitely see this game being a nice and gentle introduction for people interested in learning but unsure where to begin (and perhaps intimidated by the specification of commonly used architectures like x86). That said, it does seem like more of a puzzle game than an actual programming game. I definitely recommend moving on to learn a real entry-level instruction set like MIPS/ARM if you enjoyed learning the primitive TIS-100 language.

I recommend this game to anyone who is passionate about programming and computers, though I think the average person may find it a bit dull.

I will definitely be keeping an eye on this developer in future.

28196395.review:
Before Uncle Randy passed away, he was restoring on a broken computer. Aunt Doris gives it to you; maybe you will be able to finish his work. When you start it up, the boot sequence progresses to the whirring sound of spinning fans... Until halted by an error beep. Its memory segments are corrupted. In order to debug it, you must reprogram its various functions.

The Tessellated Intelligence System is a parallel computing architecture; it is made out of communicating nodes. The TIS-100 model has nodes configured as a 4x3 matrix.

The basic building blocks of the computer are the execution nodes. They can communicate with adjacent nodes and load data into registers for processing. Each node has a single general-purpose register and one temporary storage register that acts as a one-element stack. A multi-value stack memory node is also available.

Execution nodes can be programmed individually using the TIS instruction set. Only basic instructions are available; they support tasks such as moving data from/to register/nodes, performing basic arithmetic on the registered value and jumping to labeled sections of code.

Under this heavily constrained programming environment, the player must write programs that pass the computer's built-in test suite, rebuilding its memory segments little by little.

Very challenging game. Parallel programming is hard! Optimizing solutions requires some really heavy wizardry.

28176983.review:
Let's face it: TIS-100 is a programming system, and it that is where it shines. The instruction set for the ccomputing nodes is small yet functional, and combined with the parallel nature of the machine it gives you *a lot* of opportunities for optimization and improvements to your code.

As a programmer, I enjoy this game. I enjoy it as a fun brain teaser. It has the right balance between simplicity (no real-world machine headaches here,) and complexity (the system is powerful enough to implement meaningful programs and optimize them for various parameters in various ways.)

In short, I recommend this game heartily.

I am still not complete with this game yet, but decided to put up this review in any case, as I have nominated the game for the extra category of the Steam awards. I named the category "You Think You Can Program?"

It turns out that, despite my experience for many, many years, even some of which were spent using assembly language for various projects, I am having all sorts of trouble with this game (or assignment!).

Some of the programs are really easy to fix of course, and the overall difficulty bounces around as TIS-100 will give you an easier program if it introduces something new for you to use. But then it will usually spike back up with something more complex soon afterwards.

Right now, I am working on the "UI" coloring programs in the first set of puzzles, so I'm almost done with the main page of programs. I am interested to see what is coming next...

But I would highly recommend this game to anyone remotely interested in working out these puzzles. While some programming background does help, I imagine someone brand new to this will have a different perspective to some of the programs given the style of passing things between the blocks for the execution.

If you've never played a zacktronics game, they all have a few things in common. They're something between puzzle and algorythm design. They start off very easy. They get very hard. They will amuse you at first, but frustrate you and keep you up at night by the end.

In this one, you program an array of interconnected microcomptuers. Actually, calling them microcomputers is a vast exageration... they're more like femto-computers. Anyway, you solve a series of tasks with these machines, getting little tidbits of story along the way. Honestly, the storytelling is pretty good. There's some cool twists along the way. 

I should probably also note that I have never finished a zachtronics game. I can finish most puzzle games without breaking a sweat, but even with long hours of searching for solutions and formulating and trying different approaches, the puzzles late in a zachtronics game always get the better of me. I'm still not sure if I'm going to keep grinding on this one, forget about it, or just look up solutions so I can see how the story ends. 

This is a serious challenge, and not for the faint of heart.

28102921.review:
The gameplay consists of programming small tasks in an imaginary assembly language. However, the tasks are puzzles, which impose ridiculous restrictions. Such as, having to compare two numbers without a compare instruction and severely reducing the lines of code you can use per "node" or processor forcing the player to write micro-optimized code.

The sense of accomplishment diminishes once you actually see how un-optimized your code was, shown the global statistics. The instant feedback and comparison to other players is actually what makes the game so addicting. I refuse to quit until I reach the 'lowest amount of cycles' bracket in the scoreboard.

Oh, there is also an actual story to the mystery machine, which unveils piece by piece as the player repairs the machine by solving the puzzles, which contain messages left by the machine's previous owner.

28085489.review:
Zunächst war ich skeptisch, ob ein Spiel überhaupt dazu fähig ist, die Leidenschaft und das Erfolgsgefühl beim Programmieren von Mikroprozessoren überliefern zu können, doch dieses Spiel hat meine Zweifel beseitigt.

Auch ohne Programmierkenntnisse wird man mit diesem Spiel gut zurechtkommen, denn das beiliegende 14-seitige Manual ist knapp und umfassend geschrieben und versprüht sogar ein wenig Charme. Der Befehlssatz ist mit nur 13 Befehlen (5 davon sind Vergleichsoperatoren) sehr kompakt gehalten und kann auch im Spiel über F1 angezeigt werden. Dadurch bleibt eine lästige Suche nach Befehlen im Manual erspart und der Einstieg fällt auch nach längeren Spielpausen leicht.

Nach kurzer Eingewöhnungszeit verspricht das Spiel mit seinen durchaus anspruchsvollen Aufgaben eine wohltuende Abwechslung zum alltäglichen Programmieren zu sein. Es stellt eigene Regeln und Limitierungen auf, die zumindest für mich größtenteils ungewohnt waren.

Wie für das Programmieren üblich sollte man aber eine leichte Frustrationstoleranz und Freude am Knobeln haben, denn TIS-100 lockt mit drei verschiedenen Herausforderungen für jedes Segment: Die niedrigste Taktzahl (das schnellste Programm), die wenigsten verwendeten Programmknoten, sowie die wenigsten verwendete Befehle. Grafiken zeigen zudem an, wie gut man in den jeweiligen Bereichen abschneidet. Möchte man (jeweils) alles perfektionieren, dann ist man eine ganze Weile beschäftigt. Denn die ersten beiden Segmente sind zwar für einen seichten Anfang konzipiert, der Anspruch steigt dann aber merklich an. Nicht selten lassen sich selbst bei diesen kleinen Mikroprozessoren außerdem bewährte Optimierungsmethoden (z.B. Schleifen entrollen oder relative Sprünge) erfolgreich anwenden, wodurch das Spiel noch näher an die Realität rückt.

Die Retro-Grafik ist zwar sehr nüchtern gehalten, aber das Spiel lässt sich sowohl mit voller Mausunterstützung (Markieren), als auch sehr bequem nur mit Tastatur (Strg + Pfeiltasten) bedienen. Syntaxfehler werden markiert, Kopieren, Ausschneiden, Einfügen, Rückgängig oder Wiederholen sind implementiert - der Editor ist brauchbar gut. Die Programmknoten besitzen außerdem aufgrund ihrer Optik über stark begrenzte Textkapazitäten, ganz so, wie man es zu Pionierzeiten gewohnt war, was dem Spiel erst seinen Charakter verleiht. Jeder Knoten wird parallel ausgeführt und es wird regen Gebrauch vom Zusammenspiel und der Kommunikation dieser Knoten gemacht. Auch gibt es nur zwei Register, zwei Rechenoperationen Plus und Minus und einen Zahlenbereich von -999 bis 999, dafür ohne Überlauf. Die begrenzten Resourcen machen einen großen Teil des Charakters dieses Spiels aus.

Der nützliche Debugger (F6) zeigt für jeden Takt alle Informationen an und hilft beim Verständnis der Spielmechanik und des eigenen Programms.

Ganz nebenbei erzählt das Spiel auch noch eine kleine Geschichte über die Erfahrungen des früheren Besitzers der TIS-100. Etwas mysteriös, spirituell und ein Hauch von Verschwörungstheorie, wenn auch ohne große Wendungen und das Finale fällt etwas knapp, dafür im konsistenten Stil aus.

Mit etwas Mehraufwand ist es außerdem möglich, eigene Aufgaben zu schreiben und zu teilen, was den Wiederspielwert naturgemäß erhöht. Dadurch wird auch der (für meine Bedürfnisse passende) Schwierigkeitsgrad veränderlich. Solche Optionen sind immer lobenswert.

Mein Fazit lautet: TIS-100 ist ein vollständig durchdachtes Spiel für Prozessor-Enthusiasten... und alle anderen.

28020538.review:
It's definitely a fun little assembly game with all the cool minimal-style you need. But reviews tend to overlook that it's also a good puzzle game as well!  Besides the limit in instruction space, the limited memory per node (one main value and one backup value which you can only replace or swap with the main) and how the nodes can send and receive data between nodes physically next to each other (unless it's broken!) means you'll have to determine how to correctly move and manipulate data through space.

A loop counter might take up a node's main memory which means you need the nodes around it to send and manipulate data.  Or you might want to build a few nodes just for gatekeeping or counting that will then be used with what are essentially custom data streams, becoming a far cry from your original goal of something as simple sounding as dealing with a few loops.  What started as easy number manipulation eventually unfolds into programming that intelligently triggers sections of code.  You'll even be able to understand the solution [i]spatially[/i] because it is designed with that puzzle logic in a way most programming simply doesn't have.

And you don't need any specific programming experience (though, please, read the manual).  Absolutely a game you'll "just put 5 more minutes in", and which will keep you up late at night thinking about!

I still think about it.

27954828.review:
[h1]Ein Spiel für begeisterte Logiker[/h1]

In diesem Spiel geht es darum mit einer eigens für das Spiel erstellten Programmiersprache logikrätsel zu lösen. Programmierkentnisse sind nicht notwendig, jedoch ist es klar von Vorteil wenn man inetwa weiss wie Programme aufgebaut sind. Die Rätsel bestehen ausschlisslich aus logischen mathematischen Aufgaben, eine gewisse affinität zu Zahlen ist daher ein muss. Wer von Mathematik genervt ist oder allgemein nicht gerne mit Zahlen jongliert sollte evt die Finger davon lassen. 

[b]Pro[/b]
[list][*]Schnell zu lernen, schwer zu meistern.
[*] simples UI
[*] Als hilfestellung wird immer auch angegeben was als Resultat erwartet wird. Mittels reverse engineering können auch Leute die Englisch nicht so gut verstehen herausfinden was von ihnen verlangt wird. 
[/list]
[b]Contra[/b]
[list][*]Keine deutsche Übersetzung, Leute mit schlechten Englischkentnissen könnten schwierigkeiten haben die schwereren Aufgaben zu verstehen
[*] Kein Tutorial, obwohl die Levels langsam dann immer schneller schwerer werden, wäre ein Tutorial um die gänigsten Funktionen erklärt zu haben doch sehr Hilfreich. Vorhanden ist ist ein manual im PDF Format. Jedoch ist auch dieses in Englisch und zu allem übel noch als Bilddatei konvertiert. Heisst Textsuche kann man darin vergessen und muss sich so erst durch die Seiten kämpfen um zum entsprechenden Thema zu gelangen. Zumindest werden mittels F1 die gängigsten Funktionen im Spiel angezeigt, leider jedoch ohne ausführliche Erklärung für Menschen mit sehr wenigen oder gar keinen Programmierkentnissen. [/list]

[b]Für wen ist es geeignet?[/b]
[list][*]Spieler die gerne an logischen Rätseln tüfteln
[*] Spieler die gerne mit Zahlen arbeiten und keine abneigung gegenüber Mathe haben. 
[*] Begeisterte Spieler von Infinifactory, Human Ressource Machine, Space Chem o.ä. 
[*] Spieler mit und ohne Programmierkentnisse
[*] Nostalgiker
[*] gelangweilte Informatiker
[/list]
[b]Für wen ist es nicht geeignet?[/b]
[list][*]Dieses Spiel ist nicht geeignet als Mathenachhilfe. Wer Mathe nicht mag wird auch dieses Spiel nicht mögen und nicht spielen wollen.
[*] Spieler ohne interesse an Programmierung
[*] Spieler ohne jegliches Wissen über den Aufbau von Programmen
[*] Spieler ohne jeglichen Englischwortschatz werden es schwer haben die Aufgaben zu verstehen.
[/list]

27763651.review:
Although obviously a very different game TIS-100 has some similarities with Dark Souls that I think help explain what makes it fun:
[list]
    [*]The problems you face don't have [i]a[/i] solution. Instead, a situation with challenging parameters and restraints is presented to you and it is up to you to struggle to find something, [i]anything[/i], that works. There is a reasonable change that the solution you find will not be one that the designer had thought of. It is almost a certainty that the solution you find will not be the best one, and part of the fun in TIS-100 is trying to figure out how to improve your solution.
    [*]The problems you face are hard. Upon first glance some of them might seem impossible with the tools you've been given. Part of what makes it fun is that the challenge is genuine, and for me there is a similar sense of elation upon figuring out a TIS-100 puzzle as there is after beating a Dark Souls Boss: It had seemed like I would never do it, but I figured out a way, got better, and did it!
[/list]

While it is true that TIS-100 will likely appeal to programmers I'm not convinced that non-programmers wouldn't enjoy it. In fact, I think I would turn that statement around: If you find TIS-100 fun you would probably also enjoy programming. There are many puzzzles I've encountered in games over the years that are really programming problems, but none have been so blatant about it as TIS-100. If you are the kind of puzzle gamer who enjoys puzzles that require setting up a situation and then watching what happens when pressing GO to see if the outcome is what you expect then I would recommend giving TIS-100 a chance.

27650152.review:
TIS-100 - это игра про, как бы ни было трудно поверить, программирование на ассемблере. И она затягивает :)

Графика очень простая, практически примитивная, но стилизация великолепная. Легко поверить, что ты и в самом деле возишься с настоящим компьютером. О том что это игра, в интерфейсе не напоминает ничего, нет даже обычной и казалось бы, обязательной менюшки SAVE/LOAD/OPTIONS/EXIT.

При запуске появляется power-on self-test как на PC, крутятся килобайты протестированной памяти, потом система сообщает, что некоторые сегменты неисправны, и выводит спартанский отладочный интерфейс со списком сегментов и их статусом.

Цель игры в том, чтобы починить неисправные сегменты и запустить компьютер, а для этого для каждого из повреждённых сегментов надо написать программу, реализующую то, что делал этот сегмент. Функции сегментов, т.е. задачки - нормальные такие: поиск максимума/минимума, переворот строки, сортировка последовательности. Он начинающих программистов такое на собеседовании хотят, при этом не заставляя их писать на ассемблере с предельно ограниченными ресурсами.

Каждый сегмент состоит из процессоров-нод (до 12, обычно меньше), работающих параллельно и связанных друг с другом портами ввода-вывода. Архитектура и ассемблер совсем простые: у ноды-процессора только два регистра (мало, конечно, ну так и у настоящих процессоров их всегда меньше чем нужно :) ) - accumulator и backup (backup напрямую недоступен, используется он только для запоминания значения аккумулятора), группа команд MOV (причём можно что-то типа DMA / channel I/O - т.е. можно читать данные из одного порта и писать в другой одной MOV-командой без использования регистров, и есть аналог юниксовых poll/epoll), пара команд, копирующих accumulator в backup-регистр и обратно, базовая арифметика ADD/SUB/NEG, группа команд перехода JMP (условные, безусловный и относительный - по содержимому регистра), обязательный NOP - вот практически и всё. В лучших традициях больших систем есть недокументированная инструкция :) Да, с игрой идёт Reference Manual на архитектуру и систему команд TIS-100, помятый, исчёрканный карандашом, ключевые места выделены маркером. Стилизация великолепна, я уже говорил? :)

Когда программа готова, её можно отладить, выполняя инструкции пошагово (но шаг выполняется параллельно на всех нодах, это не делает этот процесс простым), или же запустить. Система прогонит несколько тестов - проверит, что программа выдаёт правильные ответы, как на фиксированных наборах входных данных, так и на случайно сгенерированной последовательности. Т.е. написать программу из одних MOV, тупо выдающую правильный ответ не получится, халявы не будет.

После того, как программа пройдёт все тесты, и сегмент станет рабочим, игра покажет статистику, как другие игроки справились с этой задачей, и из неё будет видно, что какой-то талант написал более быструю программу (обычно - в разы более быструю), другой - более короткую, а третий обошёлся меньшим количеством нод. И тут программистская гордость заставляет зависнуть на сегменте-уровне ещё на час-другой и сделать не хуже. :) Самое интересное, конечно - написать быструю программу, используя преимущества параллельных вычислений на нескольких нодах. И это, блин, сложно, потому что постоянно оказывается, что одна нода слишком часто ждёт данных от другой, и из-за этого распараллеленная программа нередко оказывается даже медленнее простой. Всё как на больших системах :)

В некоторых сегментах-задачах встречаются ноды-стэки (программировать их нельзя, можно только писать/читать в/из) и графический процессор. Ещё есть нерабочие ноды, у некоторых из них можно сделать дамп, в котором записаны заметки предыдущего владельца этого компьютера, немного проясняющие то, что с ним случилось. Да, в игре про ассемблер есть сюжет! Простенький, но всё же.

Итого я завис в этой штуке примерно на неделю. Но рекомендую с большой осторожностью. Всё же забава мало того, что крайне на любителя, так ещё и большая часть задач для рядового игрока будет слишком сложной (те, кому они по зубам, вполне могут заниматься тем же самым на работе и получать за это очень хорошую зарплату, а не абстрактное чувство глубокого удовлетворения и виртуальные медальки-ачивки). Но если при воспоминаниях о старых добрых временах, когда XOR AX,AX был на такт быстрее чем MOV AX,0, и это позволяло заметно ускорить свою программу, накатывает ностальгия, то игру стоит попробовать.

27601612.review:
通过编写汇编代码，根据给定的输入得到正确的输出，以完成关卡目标。《TIS-100》初看并不像是一个游戏：黑乎乎的堪比命令行的界面，不存在的新手教程，查看游戏手册也仅仅是在游戏外给你打开一个 PDF 文件而已。也许它更像是一个游戏化的编程模拟软件。

我并不知道 TIS-100 的架构是否有历史上的原型，但其的确与现实的汇编有着不小差别。指令集被精简得可怜，只支持简单的赋值、加减、判断等操作，并不支持位运算和寻址等。如果说这是为了让之前没有汇编知识的玩家能够低门槛上手的话，那只提供了一个半寄存器、限制代码的长度和宽度，就是单纯为了增加游戏的难度了。此外，和其他大多数编程题材游戏不同，它提供了多个按拓扑关系连接的节点（相当于一个处理器内核），节点与节点之间通过端口传递数据，这就需要你合理利用各个节点拆分代码，或是提供额外的寄存器，或是用来并行处理以提高程序的性能。

虽说其与现实编程存在差距，但倘若接受了这个设定，《TIS-100》就是一个相当不错的解谜游戏。对数据进行加减乘除、比较、排序、作图等，这些看似简单的功能，在游戏严苛的限制下，也成为了极具挑战性的谜题。如果你还嫌不够，你还可以尝试下完成增加了更多限制的游戏成就。此外，游戏自带了关卡编辑器，你可以下载其他玩家的谜题，也可以使用 Lua 语言编写自己的谜题考验他人。

不过过关仅仅是这游戏的一半。在你运行程序的时候，游戏会记录下你的程序使用的节点数、指令数和运行的 cycle 数（相当于运行的时间），并在好友中排名。这给了玩家不断优化程序性能的动力，也为游戏带来了较高的可重玩价值。由于这三项指标往往难以同时达到最优，游戏为每个谜题提供了 3 个存档以便于你试验各种代码结构和算法。完成一个谜题已属不易，找到它的最优解更是难上加难。当然，在这之后超越了好友，排名第一的成就感也是难以用语言来形容的。

值得一提的是，《TIS-100》并不单纯是一个程序题的集合，它还自带了一个幕后剧情。手册封面的书信、里面的涂涂画画、每个谜题中 DEBUG 节点中的日记、全是乱码的隐藏谜题，似乎都在说明这台机器背后的故事。然而作为一个还没打通第一页关卡的菜鸡码农预备役，我目前并没有余裕去探索，而 steam 评测和社区中讨论这个的人似乎也不多。希望有大神能还原它背后的故事。

然而《TIS-100》终究只能是一个小众的游戏。对于只想体验下编程思想的非程序员，相比于《Human Resource Machine》和《Lightbot》之类，它缺乏形象化的反馈，远不如它们直观和友好。对于希望用编程发挥创造力的玩家，尽管游戏有沙盒模式，但也只能做做简单的数字比较和画个分辨率感人的像素图，可发挥的余地也不大。而以程序员的角度，则可能会不满足于其过于精简的指令集和诸多严苛的限制。不过与其他编程题材的同类游戏相比，《TIS-100》很好地塑造了编程体验本身，开关机的动画音效、手敲代码的输入方式以及程序运行时的嗒嗒声等，都能让你身临其境地感受到你是在一台老机器上从事着真正的编程工作。如果你对这样的体验很感兴趣，也愿意静下心来盯着屏幕烧上几个小时的脑子，那么我向你强烈安利这款游戏。

最后说句题外话，看到有不少人希望通过这种类型的游戏来学习些编程，我想说人生苦短，还是学门 Python 、Ruby 这样的脚本语言比较好。拿这样被极度精简的类汇编语言只会让你事倍功半。

27394820.review:
This game is hard to review because it fills a very specific niche, even compared to Zachtronics' usual fare. So, before proceeding in this review, I have three questions:

Are you good at thinking outside the box?
Would you buy a game if you couldn't complete it in a couple weeks after buying it?
Can you play a game with no music, minimal sound and a bare-bones interface?

If you answered no to any of these questions, TIS-100 is not a game for you.

That out of the way, TIS-100 is still a great game. Just not for everyone. TIS-100 has 50 puzzles, each of which gives the player a goal: Take a series of numbers from up to 4 inputs, manipulate the data, and then send results to the outputs. As usual, Zach starts the player off easy, introducing concepts one at a time, and then quickly ramps up the difficulty and forces the player to test their skills with little "down time". Players will find themselves selecting maxes, sorting sequences, calculating mathematical operations and in the later stages even drawing onto a limited-color pixel canvas in accordance with the data.

Though some puzzles are incredibly difficult, even for someone with a programmer's mind like myself, Zach gives a reprieve - the player is not required to complete every puzzle in sequence to proceed; they can cherry-pick puzzles and unlock each row one by one just by completing a certain number of segments. If a particular puzzle is too difficult, the player can just choose to come back to it later. And even after the player completes a stage, there's plenty of replay value - like other Zachtronics games, each stage gives the player metrics on their performance - how many instructions they used, how long it took the program to complete the puzzle, and nodes used. After a puzzle is completed, the player gets to see how they stacked up to the data of other players, meaning there's always room for improvement.

If you're not worried about being unable to complete the game and you enjoy racking your brain for unconventional solutions, I'd definitely reccommend TIS-100.

6,5 heures de jeu effectif, une bonne dizaine de plus sur papier à côté, et un peu plus encore en journée au boulot (j'avoue, j'ai trouvé des solutions comme ça). Et je ne suis pas allé bien loin. Zachtronics nous offre un excellent jeu de réflexion/programmation que je trouve un peu moins "brutal" que Spacechem dans la difficulté. On trouve parfois vite une solution, mais ce n'est que pour bugger sur tout ce qui fait qu'elle ne marche pas "comme prévu"... 

Chaque niveau réussi est une énorme satisfaction. La petite histoire qui accompagne est agréable, et permet d'avoir un peu plus qu'une suite de puzzles balancés à la face du joueur sans autres considérations.

Bref, Zachtronics est un excellent élève quand il s'agit de jeux de ce genre, et je vais donc regarder Shenzhen I/O, leur dernière prod...

26734108.review:
This game is a whole lot of fun. If you are good at programming this game will still challenge you. 
I will go in more detail:

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The whole game is based around a little computer called the TIS-100 (Tessellated Intelligence System). The computer consists out of multiple little "Modules" that can each be programmed to do specific tasks. These modules can transfer data back and forth and can be used for simple calculations. This can be anything from adding, subtracting to harder tasks like multiplying numbers (which is way harder than you might think). Each of the modules only has 2 pieces of memory, the ACC and BAK memory. Each can be used to store one number from -999 to 999. BAK data cannot be accessed directly and can only be swapped with the ACC memory or copied from the ACC memory by using SAV. This makes the game very challenging because if you want to store 2 numbers you have to swap the ACC and BAK memory back and forth all the time or use multiple modules as storage. This system makes for some very interesting cheesy workarounds.

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]
The puzzles in the game are pretty challenging, which is a good thing. At first you will have quite a learning curve for the first few puzzles trying to figure everything out. After a while it starts making sense and you have to start thinking of ways to use the least lines of code. The timing in some puzzles may also be slightly off, every module can only do one calculation per "step", this means that if you have multiple inputs this might cause a delay making the different inputs not align properly. This adds a big challenge which I do like a lot.

All in all, this game would probably get a solid 9/10 from me :D

26585447.review:
When I was in college, I considered pursuing a career in programming and took C++ and Java classes. While I liked C++, I found Java to be rather insufferable, but came out of it with an A. However, realizing that any prospective employers might choose the language I was to program in, this meant I could end up screwed and having to program in a language I hated. Thus, I promptly stopped pursuit of anything programming-related. After playing this game, I see that I made the right choice, because holy crap is it confusing to me.

The moment I started the game, I could look at the manual, which is multiple pages of perplexing (to me) material, and when I tried to actually play the game, it took me several minutes to figure out what the "game" was and how to play it. Even after finishing the first "puzzle," I had apparently learned nothing, because I could not make any relevant progress on the second puzzle despite trying to figure out the manual and make the programming work.  

This game felt like work to me and overwhelmed me completely within moments. You will either love this game if you're able to "get it" and do well, as it will stroke your ego and make you feel smart, -or- it will leave you feeling humbled and wounded on a personal level. I fall into the latter category of player, as this has been one of the most unpleasant experiences I've ever had with a video game in my life.

Edit: Since people are flagging this as unhelpful, I'd like to add:

The game is, like other Zachtronics games, an intricate skin over a "move this thing to that thing via that other thing first" simulator. In this instance, you're putting numbers into an assembly code simulator, manipulating them in a matrix of constrained programming space using simple arithmetic/logic operators and spitting them back out according to the parameters of the level.

İlk olarak gerçekten çok güzel bir oyun olmuş, gördüğüm gibi satın aldım. Eski bilgisayarlara özlem duyan ve binlerce sayfa dökümantasyonu olmayan (IA-32 dökümantasyonu gibi), çılgınlarcasına farklı adresleme mekanizmaları olmayan (ARM mimarili sistemler gibi) basit şekilde düşük seviye programlar yazabileceğiniz bir sisteme özlem duyuyorsanız bu oyun muhtemelen çok hoşunuza gidecektir. Bunun dışında hikayedeki gizem de ayrı bir zevk veriyor. Gerkçek bir sistem olması durumunda kısıtlı komut seti, UP, LEFT, RIGHT, DOWN, ANY, LAST gibi komutlar, tek bir yazmaç olması(bu gerçekten garip), mesaj mekanizmasındaki kilitlenmeler(deadlock) yüzünden ve neden olmadığını anlayamadığım işlemci durum bayrakları yüzünden fena şekilde sövüleceğini düşünüyorum. Bunun dışında AT&T yazım şekline yakınlığından dolayı benim gibi UNIX ve GNU/Linux severlerin gönlünü kazanacağını düşünüyorum. Çok eğlenceli bir oyun olmuş emeği geçenlerin ellerine sağlık.
